diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, often leading to a range of symptoms including malar rash, serositis which can manifest as pericardial effusion, pleural effusion, and acute pericarditis, and can lead to atrophic scarring due to skin involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disease with features of three other connective tissue diseases: lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. It can present with malar rash, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In severe cases, it can cause pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, and rheumatoid nodules which might lead to scarring.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of rare diseases that involve the hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. Patients may experience atrophic scarring, and systemic involvement can lead to pleural and pericardial effusions.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. It is associated with pleural and pericardial effusions in advanced or untreated cases, and the skin rash can potentially lead to atrophic scarring.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: The growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body, most commonly the lungs and lymph nodes. It can cause pleural effusion and pericardial effusion, and skin involvement may result in scarring.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium (the fibrous sac surrounding the heart) which can be caused by viral infections. It is a common cause of acute pericarditis and can result in pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A contagious infection caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It can cause pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, and skin involvement that can lead to atrophic scarring in chronic cases.

diagnoses.name: Uremic Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: A form of pericarditis that occurs in the setting of uremia, a condition characterized by high levels of waste products in the blood due to kidney dysfunction. This can lead to acute pericarditis and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including skin rash that might lead to atrophic scarring, and in rare cases, pericardial and pleural effusions.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as malar rash (butterfly rash), leukopenia, autoimmune hemolysis, delirium (CNS lupus), and proteinuria (indicative of lupus nephritis).

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A condition that may present similarly to lupus with features of other connective tissue diseases. It could cause leukopenia, malar rash, and immune-mediated complications such as hemolysis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While more commonly associated with joint inflammation, severe cases can have systemic features, including leukopenia and autoimmune complications.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disease primarily affecting exocrine glands but can present with systemic features such as leukopenia and, albeit less commonly, neurologic symptoms like delirium.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of immune thrombocytopenia and autoimmune hemolytic anemia, which can be associated with systemic lupus erythematosus. It does not directly correlate with proteinuria, leukopenia, or a malar rash but can occur in broader autoimmune or systemic diseases that present these symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Such as microscopic polyangiitis or granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis), can cause systemic symptoms including proteinuria (due to kidney involvement) and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder can present with neurological symptoms (potentially including delirium), a malar rash in association with lupus, and renal involvement. Hematologic manifestations like leukopenia can occur.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily an infection, it can present with autoimmune phenomena such as Osler's nodes (which might be confused with malar rash), glomerulonephritis (proteinuria), and leukopenia. Autoimmune hemolysis is less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis (HLH)
diagnoses.rationale: A severe, life-threatening syndrome of excessive immune activation that can present with cytopenias, including leukopenia, and signs of systemic inflammation. It is less commonly associated with malar rash or direct autoimmune hemolysis but should be considered in a severe multisystem presentation.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: This is specifically the renal manifestation of SLE, characterized notably by proteinuria. The presence of autoimmune hemolysis, a malar rash, and leukopenia alongside suggests broader systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect multiple systems including the kidneys (leading to proteinuria) and heart (causing acute pericarditis and pericardial effusion), and may lead to leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting joints, rheumatoid arthritis can also involve the heart and kidneys, potentially leading to pericarditis, pericardial effusion, and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infections
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can cause acute pericarditis and pericardial effusion, and potentially affect the bone marrow (leading to leukopenia) and kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease often presents with features of several connective tissue diseases, including SLE, and can involve the heart and kidneys, potentially causing pericarditis, pericardial effusion, and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.rationale: Scleroderma can lead to kidney disease (manifesting as proteinuria), and cardiac involvement, often presenting with pericarditis and effusion.

diagnoses.name: Drug-Induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain medications can induce a lupus-like syndrome causing symptoms such as pericarditis, pericardial effusion, and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Kidney Disease (Chronic or Acute)
diagnoses.rationale: Kidney diseases can directly cause proteinuria and indirectly lead to cardiovascular complications including pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.rationale: Tuberculosis, especially when it disseminates, can affect various body systems, potentially leading to pericarditis, pericardial effusion, and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Cancer
diagnoses.rationale: Certain cancers, especially those affecting the blood or lymph systems, can cause leukopenia and spread or cause inflammation leading to pericarditis and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Uremia
diagnoses.rationale: Severe kidney dysfunction can lead to uremia, which can cause an array of systemic effects including pericarditis and fluid around the heart.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia (in the context of autoimmune psychosis)
Phrynoderma (Follicular hyperkeratosis due to vitamin deficiency)
Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, Epstein-Barr virus, Hepatitis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease characterized by systemic inflammation that affects multiple organs including the heart (leading to pericarditis), skin, and possibly causing fever.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder causing chronic inflammatory polyarthritis that can lead to pleural effusion, fever, and rarely pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease that leads to inflammation in various organs. The lung and lymph nodes are most commonly affected, but it can also cause pericarditis and pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: A viral infection causing fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy. It can occasionally cause pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the lymphatic system, which can cause fever, night sweats, and pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which can cause fever, pleural effusion, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed connective tissue disease
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease with overlapping features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including potential involvement of the heart and skin.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin A deficiency
diagnoses.description: Deficiency in vitamin A can lead to follicular hyperkeratosis. It is not typically associated with heart or pleural conditions but is included here due to the specific symptom mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Acute viral pericarditis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the pericardium often caused by a viral infection, presenting with acute chest pain and possibly fever.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that mainly affects children under 5 years of age, causing fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, inflammation of the blood vessels, and sometimes pericarditis.

diagnoses: Autoimmune diseases (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Rheumatoid Arthritis)
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Microscopic Polyangiitis)
Infectious diseases (e.g., viral infections, bacterial endocarditis)
Viral or post-infectious etiology (e.g., Parvovirus B19, HIV, Hepatitis)
Drug-induced lupus or other drug-induced autoimmune conditions

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), considering normal pulmonary function tests this is less likely
Viral infection (e.g., dengue fever, Zika virus)

diagnoses.name: Insulinoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of the insulin-producing cells of the pancreas that may cause hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can lead to hypotension, flushing, and difficulty focusing.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of the adrenal gland tissue causing excessive production of catecholamines, leading to symptoms like pallor and difficulty focusing.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A syndrome that occurs in individuals with carcinoid tumors, leading to symptoms such as flushing and hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by the presence of too many mast cells that can cause symptoms such as flushing and hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which the adrenal glands produce insufficient amounts of certain hormones, leading to hypoglycemia and pallor.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to symptoms like hypersensitivity to cold.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: A condition where individuals with diabetes have low blood sugar levels, causing hypoglycemia and possibly pallor.

diagnoses.name: Pancreatic Endocrine Tumor
diagnoses.description: A type of tumor that can affect hormone production in the pancreas, potentially causing hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis leading to transient Hyperthyroidism
Secondary Immunodeficiency due to Chronic Disease
Sinusitis - Complication of an underlying disease
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder affecting multiple parts of the body, including the blood vessels. This condition can cause mouth and genital ulcers, skin problems, and may affect the eyes.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including ulcers, mood changes, and more.

diagnoses.name: Cyclic Vomiting Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by episodes of severe vomiting that have no apparent cause. Episodes can last for hours or days and can be extremely debilitating.

diagnoses.name: Crohn's Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that affects the gastrointestinal tract, causing inflammation that can lead to symptoms like ulcers, vomiting, and more.

diagnoses.name: Episodic Angioedema with Eosinophilia (Gleich's Syndrome)
diagnoses.description: A rare syndrome characterized by recurrent episodes of angioedema, weight gain, fever, and an elevated number of eosinophils.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic disorder that causes recurrent episodes of severe swelling. The swelling can occur in the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway.

diagnoses.name: Narcolepsy
diagnoses.description: A chronic sleep disorder that causes overwhelming daytime drowsiness (hypersomnolence) and sudden attacks of sleep.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms include fatigue, weight gain, mood swings, and more.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder caused by high levels of cortisol in the blood. Symptoms might include weight gain, mood instability, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Hypersomnia
diagnoses.description: A sleep disorder that causes excessive daytime sleepiness (hypersomnolence) without an obvious cause, even after adequate or lengthy nighttime sleep.

diagnoses.name: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloproliferative Neoplasm
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders caused by the overproduction of blood cells by the bone marrow, leading to thrombocytosis and possibly an increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells, which can lead to thrombocytosis. May be associated with symptoms like flushing and an increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia that occurs when the body does not have enough iron, leading to fatigue which could be perceived as depression. Dysgeusia is also a known symptom.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A syndrome that occurs in some people who have carcinoid tumors, involving flushing, diarrhea, dyspnea, and in rare cases, can affect taste or lead to depression due to the physical stress.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders like systemic lupus erythematosus where the body's immune system attacks its own tissues, possibly leading to depression, increased infections, and dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A deficiency in Vitamin B12 can lead to neurological and hematological disorders that present as depression, susceptibility to infections, and altered taste (dysgeusia).

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland is underactive and produces too little thyroid hormone, leading to symptoms such as depression, fatigue, and an increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Psychological Stress
diagnoses.description: Chronic stress can lead to or exacerbate depression, weaken the immune system, thereby increasing susceptibility to infections, and induce bodily symptoms like flushing.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that involves chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, which can cause systemic symptoms like depression, increased risk of infections due to malnutrition, and dysgeusia.

diagnoses: Parvovirus B19 Infection (Erythema Infectiosum, Fifth Disease)
Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT or Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. It can also lead to an increase in white blood cells and platelets. Symptoms may include headaches, dizziness, itchiness, and sweats.

diagnoses.name: Chronic myeloid leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the bone marrow and blood. It leads to an increased number of white blood cells in the blood. Symptoms can include fatigue, night sweats, and weight loss/gain due to metabolic changes.

diagnoses.name: Essential thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which your body produces too many platelets, leading to a risk of thrombosis. Symptoms can include headaches, lightheadedness, and at times, sweats.

diagnoses.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the body lacks enough iron to produce hemoglobin, leading to various symptoms including fatigue and weakness. In some cases, it can cause an increase in platelet count.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol. Symptoms include weight gain, particularly in the upper body and around the face, and skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include weight gain, fatigue, and in some cases, an increase in platelet count.

diagnoses.name: Gastric ulcers
diagnoses.description: Sores on the lining of your stomach or small intestine. Symptoms include stomach pain, nausea, and potentially sweats if complications arise.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory bowel disease
diagnoses.description: An umbrella term for disorders that involve chronic inflammation of the digestive tract, such as Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Symptoms can include abdominal pain, diarrhea, weight loss or gain, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Infections
diagnoses.description: Various infections can cause an increase in platelet count as part of an inflammatory response, along with symptoms like fever and sweats. Examples include bacterial, viral, and fungal infections.

diagnoses.name: Metabolic syndrome
diagnoses.description: A cluster of conditions that occur together, increasing the risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. Symptoms can include excess body fat around the waist, increased blood pressure, and abnormal cholesterol or triglyceride levels.

diagnoses: Hypertensive heart and chronic kidney disease
Leukoplakia due to Epstein-Barr virus infection
Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (if considering hyperactivity in isolation)

diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder causing mouth sores, genital sores, eye inflammation, and skin rashes. It can also lead to post-nasal drip and ulcers.

A type of cancer that starts in certain blood-forming cells of the bone marrow. It can lead to an increase in white blood cells, including basophils, and can cause symptoms like fatigue and skin ulcers.
A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, potentially causing ulcers and a plethora (an excess of cells) in the blood.
An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands responsible for keeping the eyes, mouth, and other parts of the body moist and lubricated, sometimes leading to ulcers.
A chronic inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, leading to ulcers, which might indirectly cause skin issues or other symptoms.

A blood disorder in which the bone marrow makes too many red blood cells, leading to plethora. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including an itchy or burning feeling in the skin, which might be mistaken for vulvodynia.

A condition characterized by the overproduction of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell. While it does not directly cause basophilia, it is related to abnormal blood counts and can lead to ulcers and other symptoms.
An inflammatory condition that can affect the skin, mouth, or genitals, causing lesions or ulcers. It could potentially be related to vulvodynia if genital areas are involved.

A condition where mast cells release too much of their content into the bloodstream, potentially leading to a wide array of symptoms, including gastrointestinal ulcers, skin rashes, or pain in the vulvar area.
Severe allergic reactions can cause a wide range of symptoms, including post-nasal drip, skin rashes or ulcers, and sometimes increased basophil counts.

diagnoses.name: Cushing Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder caused by high levels of cortisol in the blood. It can lead to easy bruising, striae (stretch marks), and a weakened immune system.

diagnoses.name: Hyperimmunoglobulin E Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare immune disorder characterized by high levels of immunoglobulin E (IgE), recurrent skin infections like folliculitis, and lung infections.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that forms in plasma cells. It can lead to an increase in immunoglobulins, bone pain, and easy bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including chest pain, skin manifestations like striae, and increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Chest Wall Disease
diagnoses.description: Refers to a variety of conditions that affect the chest wall, leading to chest pain. Not directly related to the increase in immunoglobulins but may coexist with systemic conditions that do.

diagnoses.name: Immunoglobulin A (IgA) Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: Also known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura, this condition involves inflammation of small blood vessels. It can lead to bleeding skin lesions and abdominal and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Liver Disease/Cirrhosis
diagnoses.description: Long-term damage to the liver can cause issues with blood clotting (easy bleeding), immune dysfunctions, and various skin changes including striae.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders affecting connective tissues, characterized by skin hyperextensibility, atypical scar formation, and joint hypermobility. It may present with easy bruising.

diagnoses.name: Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by a gastrin-secreting tumor or hyperplasia of the islet cells in the pancreas that can lead to peptic ulcers, causing chest pain. It does not directly cause the increased immunoglobulins but may be associated with complex clinical presentations.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that leads to the overproduction of red blood cells. It can cause easy bruising and bleeding. It is generally not associated with increased immunoglobulins but is listed due to its hematological nature potentially affecting related laboratory results.

diagnoses: Asthma (if dyspnea is a primary symptom)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) - if history of smoking or long-term exposure to lung irritants
Vasovagal Syncope - particularly if syncope is triggered by coughing or sneezing fits
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Carbohydrate Deficient Glycoprotein Syndrome Type I

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is often accompanied by visual disturbances (aura), sensitivity to light (phonophobia), and sometimes numbness or weakness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often referred to as a mini-stroke, it can cause symptoms similar to a stroke, such as weakness and numbness, typically on one side of the body, and may also involve headache and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where there is a lack of blood flow to the brain causing cell death. Symptoms can include headache, numbness or weakness on one side of the body, and trouble speaking.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving the central nervous system. Symptoms can vary widely but often include fatigue, weakness, numbness, and difficulty in coordination.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause varying symptoms based on its location, including headache, weakness, and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, characterized by headache, fever, and neck stiffness, and can cause neurological deficits.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Migraine
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that may or may not cause a headache but includes dizziness as a primary symptom along with sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive Crisis
diagnoses.description: Severe increase in blood pressure that can lead to stroke. Symptoms may include severe headache, numbness, weakness, vision changes, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Conversion Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental condition in which a person has blindness, paralysis, or other nervous system (neurologic) symptoms that cannot be explained by medical evaluation.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, resulting in diminished function of the brain and spinal cord.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal and uncontrolled cell division occurring in the brain. Symptoms depend on the size, type, and location.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: A type of stroke caused by bleeding on the surface of the brain. It's a medical emergency.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a TIA is a brief, temporary disruption of blood flow to the brain.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection. Causes flu-like symptoms, confusion, seizures, and in severe cases, death.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A bulge or ballooning in a blood vessel in the brain. It can leak or rupture, causing bleeding into the brain.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around your nerves, leading to demyelination, which causes a range of symptoms including parasthesia, ataxia, and diplopia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that's preceded or accompanied by sensory warning signs or symptoms, such as flashes of light, blind spots, or tingling in your hand or face, photophobia, and sometimes motor disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to part of the brain, spinal cord, or retina, which can cause symptoms similar to a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Migraine
diagnoses.description: A subtype of migraine characterized by vertigo, dizziness, and imbalance in addition to or instead of the traditional migraine symptoms. It may also include photophobia, ataxia, and diplopia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms may include sudden numbness, confusion, trouble seeing in one or both eyes, and trouble walking.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause a sudden reduction of vision in the affected eye, pain with eye movement, and occasionally, symptoms affecting both eyes. Patients may experience photophobia as well.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain or close to your brain. Symptoms can include seizures, headaches, sensory changes, and depending on the tumor's location, symptoms like paresthesia, ataxia, and diplopia.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. It can lead to parasthesia, ataxia, and in severe cases, paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Arnold-Chiari Malformation
diagnoses.description: A condition in which brain tissue extends into your spinal canal, resulting in symptoms including dizziness, muscle weakness, numbness, vision problems, headaches, and problems with balance and coordination (ataxia).

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include headache, fatigue, fever, and skin rash. If untreated, it can lead to neurological problems such as paresthesia, ataxia, and facial palsy.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision, and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to muscle weakness and numbness that can reach a peak of paralysis before usually improving. Symptoms can include ataxia and parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin B12 is essential for good health. A lack of it can lead to anemia and nervous system damage. Symptoms include weakness, numbness, and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. It affects different parts of your body, including your hands and feet. Symptoms may include numbness, weakness, and pain.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, confusion, trouble speaking, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to the brain. Symptoms may be similar to those of a stroke but are temporary and should not cause permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Spinal Cord Injury
diagnoses.description: Damage to any part of the spinal cord or nerves at the end of the spinal canal. It often causes permanent changes in strength, sensation, and other body functions below the site of the injury.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection you get from the bite of an infected tick. The first sign is usually a bull's-eye rash. Early symptoms may include fever, headache, and fatigue, followed by neurological problems like ataxia.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A result of damage to the nerves located outside of the brain and spinal cord (peripheral nerves), often causes weakness, numbness, and pain, usually in your hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is a disease that causes the death of neurons controlling voluntary muscles. ALS is characterized by stiff muscles, muscle twitching, and gradually worsening weakness due to muscles decreasing in size.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headache
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache characterized by a dull, aching pain and tightness in the forehead, scalp, or neck.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headache
diagnoses.description: A condition that produces severe headaches on one side of the head, usually around the eye, along with other symptoms like redness of the eye and nasal congestion.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition caused by the interruption or reduction of blood supply to the brain, leading to brain tissue damage. Symptoms may include headache, difficulty speaking, and weakness on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it's characterized by temporary blockage of blood flow to the brain, causing short-term symptoms similar to a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can be malignant (cancerous) or benign (non-cancerous). Symptoms often include headaches, along with nausea, vomiting, and neurological deficits.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving the central nervous system in which the immune system attacks the protective covering of nerves. It can cause symptoms such as weakness, tingling, and in some cases, headache.

diagnoses.name: Intracranial Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Occurs when there is bleeding within the skull. Symptoms can include severe headache, weakness, confusion, and loss of consciousness.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, characterized by headache, fever, and stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease affecting large and medium arteries in the head, which can cause headache, scalp tenderness, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances (such as scotoma), sensory symptoms (like numbness or weakness), and a severe, often unilateral headache. Phonophobia, or sensitivity to sound, is also common.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA presents with temporary neurological dysfunction resulting from focal cerebral ischemia without acute infarction. Symptoms can include headache, weakness, numbness, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease of the central nervous system marked by numbness, weakness, balance issues, and visual disturbances. Often, these symptoms can get worse during flare-ups.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical emergency caused by either ischemia to part of the brain or hemorrhage. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, weakness, severe headache, and problems with vision.

diagnoses.name: Hemiplegic Migraine
diagnoses.description: A rare form of migraine headache that can mimic a stroke, as it may cause temporary paralysis (hemiplegia), sometimes preceding or accompanying a headache. Vision changes, numbness, and phonophobia may also be present.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain or the skull vault. Symptoms depend on the tumor's location but can include headache, weakness, numbness, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Venous Sinus Thrombosis (CVST)
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a blood clot forms in the brain's venous sinuses. This prevents blood from draining out of the brain, leading to increased intracranial pressure, causing headache, weakness, numbness, and possibly visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause partial or complete loss of vision, usually in one eye, along with pain that gets worse with movement of the eye. While not typically associated with weakness or numbness, it is a common symptom of multiple sclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges. Symptoms include severe headache, fever, neck stiffness, and can also include a decreased level of consciousness. Visual problems, weakness, and numbness can also occur, albeit less commonly.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks part of the peripheral nervous system. The first symptoms are typically weakness and tingling in the extremities, which can spread and intensify into paralysis. The exact cause is unknown, but it's often preceded by an infectious illness.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden weakness, difficulty speaking or understanding speech, and visual problems.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to the brain. It can cause symptoms similar to a stroke, including weakness, speech problems, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can press on nerve cells in the brain, leading to symptoms such as weakness, difficulty speaking, swallowing problems, and changes in vision, depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause symptoms such as weakness, difficulties in speech (dysarthria or aphasia), and swallowing problems.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraine with aura is a type of migraine that involves visual disturbances (scintillations) and other neurological symptoms that start before the headache and usually last less than an hour. Symptoms could also include weakness and language disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, ALS affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord, causing loss of muscle control. Symptoms include difficulty swallowing, weakness, and speech problems.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the arms and legs. The primary symptoms include muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing, double vision, and difficulties in speech.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing the whole body. Guillain-Barre syndrome is a medical emergency.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus that develops in response to an infection or trauma. Symptoms may include headache, fever, nausea, vomiting, neurological deficits such as weakness, difficulty speaking, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Vertebral Artery Dissection
diagnoses.description: A tear in the vertebral artery, which is located in the neck and supplies blood to the brain. This can lead to a stroke. Symptoms can include headache, neck pain, vision problems, difficulty swallowing, weakness, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden weakness, difficulty speaking or understanding speech (aphasia), and numbness of the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraine with aura is a type of migraine that involves neurological disturbances such as visual disturbances (scotoma), numbness, and speech difficulties (aphasia). These symptoms typically precede the headache phase and can also include symptoms such as nausea.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a disease of the central nervous system in which the immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Common symptoms include fatigue (weakness), numbness or weakness in one or more limbs, partial or complete loss of vision (scotoma), and issues with speech (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: A transient ischemic attack (TIA), often called a mini-stroke, features symptoms similar to those of a stroke but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage. Common symptoms include weakness, speech disturbances (aphasia), numbness or paralysis of the face, arm, or leg, and visual disturbances (scotoma).

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can vary greatly depending on the tumor's size, location, and growth rate. They might include headaches, weakness, speech difficulties (aphasia), numbness, nausea, and visual disturbances (scotoma).

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. Early symptoms include fever, headache, nausea, and stiffness of the neck. Some people may also experience symptoms like confusion, seizures, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Aphasia and numbness can occur after a seizure.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: Vertebrobasilar insufficiency is a condition resulting from a restricted blood supply to the back of the brain. Symptoms can include dizziness, vision problems, including scotoma, weakness, nausea, and in serious cases, stroke-like symptoms such as aphasia and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre Syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord. It causes loss of muscle control. Symptoms include weakness, muscle cramps, and speech disturbances (aphasia) as the disease progresses.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. In some cases, migraines are preceded by visual disturbances known as auras, which can include scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical emergency caused by the interruption of blood supply to the brain, leading to brain tissue damage. Symptoms can include sudden numbness or weakness, especially on one side of the body, confusion, trouble speaking, difficulty walking, dizziness, and severe headache.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, vision problems, and impaired coordination.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often referred to as a 'mini-stroke,' a TIA is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It doesn't cause lasting damage but may be a warning for future strokes.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Its symptoms can include headaches that worsen in the morning, nausea, vomiting, changes in speech or hearing, problems with vision, and weakness or loss of motor function.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing severe dizziness (vertigo), ringing in the ears (tinnitus), hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuronitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the vestibular nerve, a nerve in the ear that helps control balance. This condition causes sudden, severe vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: An abscess caused by an infection in the brain. Symptoms can include headache, fever, weakness, mental confusion, seizures, and problems with vision.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from restricted blood flow to the back of the brain, causing dizziness, double vision, slurred speech, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive Encephalopathy
diagnoses.description: A rare condition caused by extremely high blood pressure leading to swelling in the brain, resulting in symptoms such as headache, nausea, vomiting, confusion, and seizures.

diagnoses: Chronic Ear Infections (leading to tinnitus and possibly other symptoms)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if unrelated to other symptoms)
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Epilepsy (in the context of CNS involvement by systemic disease)
Viral infection (e.g., HIV, Epstein-Barr virus, COVID-19)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Infectious causes (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C-related cryoglobulinemia)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
